subject: Re: Junit 3 suite setup tear down
msgSnippet: ... class. ... How does this help? I want to be able to run ANY (sub)set of the methods from arbitrary set of test-classes.
messageBody:
--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "David Saff" <david@...> wrote:
>
> On Thu, Sep 18, 2008 at 8:21 AM, toalexsmail <toalexsmail@...> wrote:
> > --- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "David Saff" <david@> wrote:
> >>
> >> On Mon, Aug 11, 2008 at 3:05 PM, toalexsmail <toalexsmail@> wrote:
> >> > Perhaps, you meant to use something like this
> >> >> @RunWith(Suite.class)
> >> >> @SuiteClasses(A.class, B.class)
> >> >> public class MySuite {
> >> >> @BeforeClass public static void doYourOneTimeSetup() {}
> >> >> @AfterClass public static void doYourOneTimeTeardown() {}
> >> >> }
> >> > ?
> >> > First of all, until recently I wasn't aware of this opportunity.
> >> > Second of all, it is quite verbose and not very flexible.
> >>
> >> toalexsmail,
> >>
> >> I'm sorry for the long delay in answering. Can you explain how you
> >> would like it to be more flexible? Thanks,
> >>
> >> David Saff
> >>
> > I think I did mentioned this. In short, this approach force me to
> > write one more class, and I can't run only some methods within the
class.
>
> In this case, does it make more sense to handle it outside the JUnit
> framework entirely, using a Singleton pattern?
>
> David
>
How does this help? I want to be able to run ANY (sub)set of the
methods from arbitrary set of test-classes.
